repnme.cdata!:
Dominican Republic - Electricity
            Distribution Rehabilitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Electricity Distribution
            Rehabilitation Project for Dominican Republic (DR) were as
            follows: outcomes were moderately satisfactory, risk to
            development outcome was moderate, Bank performance was
            moderately satisfactory, and Borrower performance was
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: the
            project implementation unit (PIU) at Corporacion Dominicana
            de Empresas Electricas y Estatales (CDEEE) learned that is
            necessary to reduce the scope of bidding processes (or to
            set a cap on the maximum number of areas that a single
            company can win) to increase the number of participating
            contractors and reduce the risk of no delivery; without this
            provision very large companies tend to win the bids
            increasing the project's vulnerability to delays and
            low quality of service. The basic and design engineering
            have to be conducted when the resources are available to pay
            for the rehabilitation works, considering that long delays
            in the project (including in reaching effectiveness and in
            the launching of bidding process) render the engineering
            work outdated as the system changes with demand growth and
            other modifications. The choice of cash recovery index (CRI)
            as an indicator that reflects progress in the financial
            sustainability of distribution companies was not necessarily
            appropriate in the context of the power sector in the DR.
            Empresas Distribuidoras de Electricidad (EDEs) financial
            sustainability is affected by a number of other variables
            including the debt service associated with the loans issued
            to purchase fuel oil and direct cash transfers from the
            government to cover this debt. Lessons learned in monitoring
            and evaluation (M and E) is the need to impose third audit
            access of EDEs' primary data as condition for
            concessionary support to ensure the quality of M and E
            results. The PIU has learned that it is important to include
            the installation of meters and other accessories (commercial
            infrastructure) in the works associated with the
            rehabilitation of circuits to avoid delays in service
            provision and the regularization of billing. The design of
            the social component, which included a strong social
            management plan that introduced a seven step process as a
            strategy for community outreach was extremely successful in
            both bringing the community on board and substantially
            improving the revenue collection of the utilities as well as
            quality of service to consumers.

17323040.theme: Infrastructure services for private sector development

repnme.cdata!:
Dominican Republic - Electricity
            Distribution Rehabilitation Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objectives of the
            Electricity Distribution Rehabilitation Project for the
            Dominican Republic are to: (a) increase the cash recovery
            index of the three electricity distribution companies, and
            (b) improve the quality of electricity service. The closing
            date for the Project will be extended from December 31, 2012
            until June 30, 2013. The Project Management, development
            objectives and implementation progress are rated
            satisfactory through July 2, 2012. To date, 69 percent of
            the Loan has been disbursed and the three main procurement
            contracts, for a total of US$37 million are being
            implemented. The three contracts were approved by the CDEEE
            (Corporacion Dominicana de Empresas Electricas Estatales)
            Board of Director on September 28, 2010, and project
            originally had an implementation period of 20 to 23 months.
            The changes of implantation unit will not affect the
            development objective, activities, indicators, or any other
            aspect of the three components that comprise the Project:
            (i) rehabilitation and upgrading of medium and low voltage
            circuits (US$37 million), (ii) outreach to consumer
            communities (US$3 million), and (iii) technical assistance
            (US$2 million). The extension is necessary to ensure timely
            progression in the implementation, providing a time buffer
            for contractors to complete their work and the implementing
            agency to complete necessary administrative paperwork. This
            will be the first extension of the closing date for the project.
